titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid for the Yoshie Yoshida Papers LSC.2350
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Kelly Besser, 2021.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2021 January 11.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-19 16:19:38 -0700.

did.abstract: As an art critic and curator, Yoshie Yoshida (1929-2016) organized many exhibitions and events in Japan. After becoming a member of Art Critics Association, he was also engaged in supporting political and performance art. The collection ranges from monographs, serials and audiovisual material to scrapbooks, article clippings, exhibition programs, posters and correspondence.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
did.langmaterial: Materials are mostly in Japanese, with some in English and Portuguese.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains processed audiovisual materials. All requests to access digital materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of Item], Yoshie Yoshida papers (Collection 2350). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

acqinfo.head: Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The acquisition was through the gift of the Yoshida family, with the assistance of Yoshiko Shimada (who compiled the archival materials into files) and William Marotti, in 2016. The "Kazuko Tsujimura" folder was donated by Tsujimura's brother to Yoshiko Shimada and added to the collection in 2017.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Physical processing performed by Wil Lin and Hannah Moshier and intellectual processing performed by Junko Tanaka, under the guidance of Courtney Dean, 2017-2018.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Yoshie Yoshida, an art critic, curator, and event/exhibition organizer, was born in Japan in 1929. In the 1950s he carried Matsuki's Hiroshima Panels throughout Japan as a travelling exhibit. Upon publishing a book "Takiguchi Shuzo oboegaki" in 1961, he became a member of Art Critics Association. In 1965, he founded an artist-run gallery, Modern Art Center of Japan. Yoshida organized an art performance, Haisen Bansankai (Dinner Party Commemorating WWII Defeat, 1962) and Festival of Humans and Earth (1970). He also supported political art such as Akasegawa Genpei's 1000-yen Trial (1965-67) and anti-expo art movement (1969). He died in Tokyo, Japan, in 2016. Among his works are "Kaitaigeki no maku orite: 60-nendai zen'ei bijutsushi" (avant-garde art history in the 60s) in 1982, and "Matsuzawa Yutaka Pusai no hako" (1983) where Yoshida edited the portfolio of the artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection was created by an art critic Yoshie Yoshida (1929-2016), and ranges from monographs, serials and audiovisual material to scrapbooks, article clippings, exhibition programs, posters and correspondence. Monographs center on exhibition catalogs, materials on surrealism, and books by/on particular artists (Shuzo Takiguchi, Genpei Akasegawa and Yutaka Matsuzawa). Serials chiefly consist of newsletters from art museums and institutes. An extensive amount of materials and documents are also found on Butoh (a Japanese avant-garde dance form). Other materials and documents cover social, political as well as artistic events/movements in which Yoshida was involved, such as Ningen to Daichi no Matsuri (Festival of Humans and Earth), Sanrizuka Struggle and Artist Union.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes Anti-Expo statements by Yoshida and items on Modern Art Center of Japan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes documents on 1000-yen Note Trial and Utopia and Visions Exhibition Q&A.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Articles from "Artist Union" newsletters, articles on Artist Union, and programs of Artist Union Symposiums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Flyers for assemblies, articles and newsletters relating Sanrizuka Struggle (a series of protests against the construction of Narita Airport in Tokyo). Includes items on Issaku Tomura (Protest Coalition leader) Exhibition, curated by Yoshida.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Articles, flyers and correspondence on Cosmos Exhibition held in Sao Paulo in 1974. Files composed by Yoshida. Includes Yoshida's journals during the exhibition and Brazilian trip.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Photographs, correspondence, programs, articles relating to the event organized by Yoshida. Contains documentation on the event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This file has "Ozaki" (event co-organizer) written on cover, and centers on correspondence and mail art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Chiefly letters and postcards from artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Articles, flyers and program on the Exhibition held in Chicago, 1978, organized by Yoshida.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: A military artist directory and articles on war/military art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Programs, flyers and newsletters related to Butoh (Japanese avant-garde dance form). Contains letters from Yoko Ashikawa (Tatsumi Hijikata's student and collaborator).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Photos, books and correspondence. Includes Liberty Passport from Takiguchi and photos by Mitsutoshi Hanaga.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Photocopy of a three-volume autobiography written by Hironae Yoshida (Yoshida's father).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of Yoshida's portraits and correspondence with Yoshida, collected by Kazuko Tsujimura.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Ten VHS tapes, including Nobuyuki Oura's "Enkin o kakaete," Butoh performances, and videos featuring Isao Mizutani and Takami Sakurai.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: COLLECTION CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Posters and photographs for exhibitions and events, including 1000-yen Note Trial 1965 Matsuzawa Yutaka "Pusai no itai ni tsuite" 1964 Photographs for the Festival of Humans and Earth posters 1971 Global Art Vision 1971 Urban Open Space in Hiroshima 1972 Hi-red Center 1966?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Postcards, flyers and programs for exhibitions and events organized by Yutaka Matsuzawa. Also includes correspondence from Matsuzawa to Yoshida. Two issues of "Art & Project bulletin" are in English.
